articles.headline: Jeb Bush Faces Challenge in Winning Over Brother’s Team
articles.snippet: While many in George W. Bush’s circle are enthusiastic, many of those who worked for him have not rushed to join his brother’s emerging 2016 operation.
articles.abstract: While many in George W. Bush’s circle are enthusiastic, many of those who worked for him have not rushed to join his brother’s emerging 2016 operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When George W. Bush first ran for president, he liked to say he had inherited half of his father’s friends and all of his enemies. For Jeb Bush, now preparing his own bid for the White House, that may ring familiar.

articles.headline: Caitlyn Jenner, Formerly Bruce, Introduces Herself in Vanity Fair
articles.snippet: An Olympic gold medalist, author, actor and reality television star discusses her transition to a woman in an article in the magazine.
articles.abstract: An Olympic gold medalist, author, actor and reality television star discusses her transition to a woman in an article in the magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: In April, Bruce Jenner spoke about her transition to being a woman in a television special that drew nearly 17 million viewers.

articles.headline: Drought Is Bearing Fruit for Washington Wineries
articles.snippet: The state, which has long lagged California in winemaking, has seen its industry double in the last 15 years, and the expansion may be accelerating.
articles.abstract: The state, which has long lagged California in winemaking, has seen its industry double in the last 15 years, and the expansion may be accelerating.
articles.lead_paragraph: YAKIMA, Wash. — American wine, for all the hype and hyperbole in recent years about Idaho rieslings or Pennsylvania pinot noirs, is still overwhelmingly a California thing. Even in an off year, wineries there produce more than 20 times as much wine as the vineyards here in Washington State, the perennial No. 2 in the rankings.

articles.headline: Hundreds Missing After Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks on Yangtze
articles.snippet: China’s official news agency said the ship sank Monday night in a storm, and as of Tuesday morning, local media reported the rescue of only a small number of people.
articles.abstract: China’s official news agency said the ship sank Monday night in a storm, and as of Tuesday morning, local media reported the rescue of only a small number of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Most of the 458 people aboard a chartered cruise ship in China were still missing on Tuesday morning, more than a dozen hours after the vessel sank during a torrential rainstorm along the central Yangtze River, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.

articles.headline: Reflections on Stress and Long Hours on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Wall Street has always thrived, in part, on its eat-or-be-eaten culture. Would curbing its competitive nature cut into its success?
articles.abstract: Wall Street has always thrived, in part, on its eat-or-be-eaten culture. Would curbing its competitive nature cut into its success?
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, a 22-year-old first-year analyst at the Goldman Sachs office in San Francisco was feeling overwhelmed by the all-nighters and 100-hour workweeks.

articles.headline: Seeking Rate Increases, Insurers Use Guesswork
articles.snippet: Many insurers say they are asking for higher premiums because they remain unsure about the future and what their medical costs will be.
articles.abstract: Many insurers say they are asking for higher premiums because they remain unsure about the future and what their medical costs will be.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of the tumult in the health insurance industry under the Affordable Care Act, companies are seeking wildly differing rate increases in premiums for 2016, with some as high as 85 percent, according to information released on Monday by the federal government for the 37 states using HealthCare.gov as their exchange.

articles.headline: In Debate Over Patriot Act, Lawmakers Weigh Risks vs. Liberty
articles.snippet: Even if Congress restricts domestic surveillance, the counterterrorism infrastructure built in recent years has become firmly embedded in society.
articles.abstract: Even if Congress restricts domestic surveillance, the counterterrorism infrastructure built in recent years has become firmly embedded in society.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just one senator voted against the Patriot Act, calling it a violation of civil liberties when it passed in the frightening, angry days after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Nearly 14 years later, 77 senators voted to advance a bill ratcheting back its expansive scope.

articles.headline: European Leaders Assemble for Urgent Meeting on Greek Crisis
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is under mounting pressures from many sides, and European leaders hope to help his cash-starved country swiftly meet its financial obligations.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece is under mounting pressures from many sides, and European leaders hope to help his cash-starved country swiftly meet its financial obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As the Greek government faces a looming debt payment, top European leaders met in Berlin on Monday night to reach a consensus over what to do about Greece, signaling the urgent need to unlock emergency financing for the cash-starved country and avoid a devastating default.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman, Niki Kitsantonis and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Few Triumphs in Frantic Hunt for 430 in Yangtze River
articles.snippet: More than a day after the Oriental Star capsized in Hubei Province, China, most of the people on board were still missing.
articles.abstract: More than a day after the Oriental Star capsized in Hubei Province, China, most of the people on board were still missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: JIANLI, China — Zhu Hongmei, 65, had somehow managed to work her way into an air pocket in the capsized cruise ship. She stayed there for 15 or so hours despite the cold and the currents and the darkness.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: U.S. Surveillance in Place Since 9/11 Is Sharply Limited
articles.snippet: A bill to allow the government to restart surveillance operations, but with new restrictions, passed over the opposition of the Senate majority leader, and was signed by President Obama.
articles.abstract: A bill to allow the government to restart surveillance operations, but with new restrictions, passed over the opposition of the Senate majority leader, and was signed by President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a significant scaling back of national security policy formed after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, the Senate on Tuesday approved legislation curtailing the federal government’s sweeping surveillance of American phone records, and President Obama signed the measure hours later.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Jonathan Weisman
